official-title.#text:
To amend title 10, United States Code, to extend military
		  commissary and exchange store privileges, without time-period limitation, to
		  members of the Armed Forces who are involuntarily separated with a
		  service-connected disability and also to extend such privileges to their
		  dependents.

cosponsor.#tail:
) introduced
			 the following bill; which was referred to the

header.#text:
Commissary and exchange store
			 privileges for involuntarily separated members with a service-connected
			 disability and for their dependents

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, is amended by adding at the end the following new
			 subsection:
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
Section 1146 of
			 title 10, United States Code

text.#text:
A member of the armed forces who is
				involuntarily separated from active duty or the Selected Reserve and who has a
				service-connected disability shall be permitted to use commissary and exchange
				stores on the same basis as a member of the armed forces entitled to retired or
				retainer pay.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall be permitted to use commissary and exchange stores on the
				same basis as a dependent of a member of the armed forces entitled to retired
				or retainer
				pay.

text.#text: A dependent of a member described in

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
subsection (d) of section 1146 of title
			 10, United States Code

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, is fully operational before
			 the end of the 90-day period beginning on the date of the enactment of this
			 Act.

{http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/}title.#text: 113 HR 1131 IH: To amend title 10, United States Code, to extend military commissary and exchange store privileges, without time-period limitation, to members of the Armed Forces who are involuntarily separated with a service-connected disability and also to extend such privileges to their dependents.

{http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/}rights.#text: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
